content: ⚠️ Modified the contribution: Swapped Validator #4 and Test #4 and added an explicit round up check to test 4. Additionally made all tests have a trailing newline instead of only some test cases having trailing newline.
This needs testcases where the need for rounding is crucial, so far this seems to be only in the validators.

I would love to see you solve this in C. It is way too complicated for a 15 minute clash. Eval is a cool hack to be used sparingly, relying on it as the only viable solution is bad even in languages that have it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's easy and fun

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice test for shortest, good for getting comfortable with eval. I like that the rounding was included - a good way to catch people who submit without reading all the rules or running all the tests.
Is it not a bit unfair for programming languages which has no evaluation operator ?

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment:
Nice clash! Perfect for shortest.
eval is not so necessary to put it into the solution. U can use the "int(a) in ur list comp too

Goal section and Input section
* Please replace "rows" with "lines" to be consistent.

Input section
* Please delete ": N lines containing".

Output section
* Please change "[[N]] lines" to "<<[[N]] lines:>>".

Constraints section
* Suggest to change 100 to 10.
* Please specify that all operations will not result in any fractions.

Cases
* The current outputs are inconsistent in formatting - some contain ".0" and some do not. Please fix your code so that none of the outputs will show ".0".
* Suggest to switch test 3 and test 4 because none of the tests currently suggest that negative numbers may be provided in the operations.

Thanks.

Thank you for your feedback ! I appreciate it.

Could you tell me why it is better to avoid fractions or provide negative numbers? 

Thanks.

Thanks for the comment !
I think that the eval( ) method is more appropriate for processing a complete string expression with all given operations. 

int( ) can be used too! but I think the code will be more complex and longer. (using int( ) with a string not representing a number will generate an error)
Thank You ! :)
Thank you ! :)

Thanks for comment !
I'm not sure about the presence of eval in all programming languages but it exists in many of them such as Perl, PHP, JavaScript, Ruby, Python...
Still, the problem can be solved without eval like doing multiple splits(the code can be longer) or maybe with a brilliant idea !
Thank you ! :)
Thank you ! :)

Thank you for the comment !

I thought of using two variables, one to store each number (like adding all the digits to a string until we meet an operator, then converting to int) and the other for the result of each operation using conditions, it works but it will be a bit long. What do you think about it?

btw some have solved it using Ruby and JavaScript in less than 15min.

Thank you for the comment!

the rounding takes effect in Test3 and Test4 with their validators. Could you provide more detail on the lack you perceived?

I think that's a lot of code to write within the time constraints of a clash, especially considering parsing a single operation is only a part of the full problem. You'd have to be an expert in C to have any chance to complete it on time.

There is no problem with languages like Ruby and JS, the problem is trivial with eval. I could probably just about do it without eval in 15 minutes (in Ruby or Python) but that's only because it's possible to abuse weak test cases (there are no tests to check you've handled parens and operator precedence correctly).

The point is not that fractions should be avoided. The issue is that if fractions are involved, you have to specify clearly the output requirements (rounding up or down or to the nearest integer/number of decimal places? how many decimal places should be shown?).

Seeing that division won't result in any fractions, that was why I asked you to add that constraint to make things clear. Without the constraint, the player won't know how to deal with decimal places.

Regarding the point on negative numbers: I see that you have named all the cases as "Test", but remember that tests and validators are different: during a clash, the player is able to see all tests but not the validators. However, the code is assessed using the validators, not the tests. So it will be frustrating for a player if he passes all tests by writing a code that doesn't consider negative numbers, but then fails some validators because those involve negative numbers.

So again it is not that negative numbers should be avoided. The point is that a player should see tests with sufficient coverage, and validators should be similar to tests to avoid nasty surprises.

Comments to follow up:

Input section
* Please replace "rows" with "lines" to be consistent.
* Please delete the extra colon before "a string".

Thanks.

Thank you for this clarification ! 

I'll improve it.
Good :) Also remember that tests and validators should be similar and not the same.
Perfect ! Okay I'll fix that

OK. Just some reminders for your fix:

The following two lines are not constraints. They should be moved to the Goal section:
"The result of each line should be rounded to 0."
"Negative numbers are taken into account."

Also "rounded to 0" should be changed to "rounded to the nearest integer".

Cases of division and negative numbers are better to be added as additional cases - I mean you are not limited to 4 pairs of tests and validators, you can have more pairs.

Also, remember to revise the 3rd pair and the 4th pair - the tests and validators of those pairs are the same at the moment.

Thanks again ! I appreciate it.
How about now, is this good ?
Yes, better now, thanks.
Thank you!  :)
